newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: Clariant to decide later on dyestuffs.
newsitem.headline: Clariant to decide later on dyestuffs.

text.p: Swiss specialty chemicals maker Clariant AG told a newspaper it expected to decide later this year "what will happen" with its textile dyestuff business, which Germany's DyStar GmbH has said it was interested in.
The Swiss business bi-weekly Finanz und Wirtschaft quoted Clariant chairman Rolf Schweizer as saying his group was generally interested in actively managing its portfolio of business areas.
"A swap, sale or acquisition of particular product lines is always possible if it serves the goals we have set," he said in an interview.
"DyStar has in fact shown interest in our textile dyestuff business, as other competitors have also done," Schweizer said.
"We will probably decide in the second half of the year what will happen with our dyestuff business," he added without elaborating.
DyStar said on May 27 it would be interested in obtaining the textile dyestuff business from Clariant but that it was not in a position to make a decision.
"We are interested, but the decision making process rests with someone else," DyStar general manager Alfred Rad told a news conference.
DyStar, the world's leading textile dyestuff company, is jointly owned by German chemical giants Bayer AG and Hoechst AG.

It was thrust into a difficult position when Hoechst last December announced it was taking a 45 percent stake in DyStar's competitor Clariant as partial payment for selling Hoechst Speciality Chemicals to the Swiss group.
